**China to stick with 'around 5%' GDP target in 2025 despite Trump win: economist**
China is expected to maintain its economic growth target of 'around 5%' in 2025, despite the potential trade shock from increased tariffs under Donald Trump's second term as US president. According to Zhang Ming, deputy director of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences' Institute of Finance and Banking, China's economy may slow in early 2025, but is expected to pick up momentum later in the year to achieve the annual growth target. Zhang warned that the tariff shock from Trump's inauguration will have a significant negative impact on China's export growth in 2025, as exports account for around 20% of China's total gross domestic product, with the United States being one of its biggest trading partners.

Publish date: November 08, 2024 03:00 AM
Source:[South China Morning Post](https://www.scmp.com/economy/policy/article/3285676/china-stick-around-5-gdp-target-2025-despite-trump-tariff-threat-economist)

**China's Exports Surge, but Imports Decline Amid Trade Uncertainties**
China's exports have increased by 12.7% in October compared to the previous year, exceeding expectations of a 5% growth. However, imports have decreased by 2.3% in the same period. Experts attribute the export growth to possible catch-up effects after previous disruptions at Chinese ports due to storms. Additionally, companies in the US may have stockpiled goods in anticipation of a Trump presidency and subsequent trade tensions. The decline in imports suggests that consumer spending in China remains sluggish. The Chinese economy has been struggling due to factors such as the ongoing housing market crisis, weak domestic demand, and high youth unemployment. To boost the economy, the central bank has lowered interest rates for mortgage loans. Observers hope for further measures, which could be announced this week. A potential Trump presidency could bring new uncertainties for Chinese trade, as he initiated a trade war with China during his first term by imposing high tariffs, leading to significant tensions. Experts fear that an escalation of the trade conflict could harm the economic recovery in China and globally. A spokesperson for the Chinese Foreign Ministry declined to comment on hypothetical questions about new US tariffs, stating that there would be no winner in a trade war, which would not benefit the world. German companies in China may further increase local production in response to new tariffs, according to the German Chamber of Commerce in China. Companies that invested in costly diversification and localization since the start of the US-China trade conflict are now seeing their efforts confirmed, as further trade barriers are expected. 'We assume that German companies will continue to localize their global production sites and supply chains,' said Maximilian Butek, executive board member of the German Chamber of Commerce in East China. The trade between China and Germany was sluggish in October, with Chinese exports to Germany increasing by 5.2% below average, while imports decreased by 11.2%. 'The declining imports from Germany can be explained by the weak domestic demand and the fact that customers increasingly prefer Chinese products, which are improving in quality and becoming more price-competitive,' said Butek.

**Why China's economy would be more vulnerable to Trump tariffs this time**
A potential 60% tariff on Chinese goods by Donald Trump, who has been elected as the next US president, poses significant growth risks for China's economy. Unlike his first term, the economy is now in a more vulnerable position due to a property market crisis, unsustainable debt, weak domestic demand, and deflationary pressures. The property market downturn has saddled local governments with debt, while low wages and pensions, high youth unemployment, and a feeble social safety net have left household spending below 40% of GDP. China's ability to respond to external growth shocks is limited, and the yuan's depreciation may not fully offset the tariff impact. Other factors, such as the COVID-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, have provided unexpected opportunities for China, but these are unlikely to be repeated. 'China may be able to boost external sales in areas where its economy is extremely competitive, but has little control on external demand,' according to the article. 'The burden is huge, limiting China's ability to respond to any external growth shocks,' it adds.

**China’s factory output appears to be growing again**
China's factory output appears to be growing again after five consecutive months of contraction. The official manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) reached 50.1 in October, beating expectations, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Julian Evans-Pritchard, head of China economics at Capital Economics, said that readings above 50 typically indicate expanding economic activity. Lynn Song, chief economist for Greater China at ING, noted that while 50.1 is the smallest possible expansion, it is a positive sign. Xu Tianchen, senior economist at the Economist Intelligence Unit, attributed the figure to the early impact of higher fiscal support, enabled by an acceleration in government bond issuance. Other signs of the stimulus measures taking effect include the non-manufacturing PMI rising to 50.2 and an easing of the youth unemployment rate.

China's manufacturing sector is looking more optimistic about its business, according to the National Bureau of Statistics in Beijing. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) in October was 50.1 points, 0.3 points higher than the previous month, marking the first time since April that the indicator has exceeded 50 points. This suggests an expansion of industrial activity. A Bloomberg survey had predicted the PMI to be below 50 points. The non-manufacturing sector, including construction and services, also saw an increase in activity, with the PMI rising to 50.2 points from a neutral 50. Experts hope that the government's announced measures to boost the economy will continue, as the country aims to achieve a 5% economic growth rate this year. However, the economy has been struggling due to a housing market crisis, weak domestic demand, and high youth unemployment. The People's Bank of China has already lowered interest rates for mortgage loans to stimulate spending. Further measures are expected to be announced in the coming week.

**China's Youth Unemployment Rate Decreases to 17.6% in September**
China has announced that the unemployment rate for 16-24 year olds has slightly decreased to 17.6% in September, a figure closely watched as the country tries to revive its slowing economy. This rate, which does not include high school students and university students, is still high but lower than the 18.8% recorded in August, the highest level since the beginning of 2024, according to the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) of China. The increase in the number of university graduates in June, with nearly 12 million students obtaining their diplomas, has added to the competition on the already difficult job market, which explains the sharp rise in unemployment this summer and its slight decline last month as some hiring took place. Xi Jinping, the Chinese president, had declared in May that fighting youth unemployment should be considered an 'absolute priority'. The unemployment rate for 25-29 year olds has also decreased from 6.9% in August to 6.7% in September, and the overall unemployment rate for the country has decreased from 5.3% to 5.1%.

**China's Youth Unemployment Rate Decreases Slightly After Two Months of Increase**
According to the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) of China, the youth unemployment rate in the country has decreased slightly after two months of increase. The rate, which affects people between 16 and 24 years old, rose significantly during the summer, from 13.2% in June to 17.1% in July and 18.8% in August, a record high after the authorities revised the methodology of the indicator at the end of last year to exclude students. The poor employment data for young people in the summer was due to the entry of a record number of graduates into the labor market - an estimated 12 million this year - and increasingly bleak job market prospects, affected by the slowdown in the recovery of the world's second-largest economy, reported local media. The Chinese government has made youth employment a top priority, both due to the negative impact on consumption of potential income decline and the risks to social stability, a vital issue for Beijing. Chinese authorities expressed confidence on Friday that the world's second-largest economy 'will continue on a trend of stabilization and recovery', after announcing a stimulus package with measures to support the financial and real estate sectors and the stock market, in order to relaunch the recovery of the world's second-largest economy. Analysts stated that the package of measures is 'a step in the right direction', but 'insufficient' to relaunch the economic recovery of China, unless accompanied by an increase in public spending, a question that may collide with concerns about the sustainability of the debt. Low domestic and international demand, associated with risks of deflation, insufficient stimuli, housing crisis, and lack of confidence from consumers and the private sector are some of the causes pointed out by analysts to explain what is happening in the world's second-largest economy.

**China's Young People Adopt 'Revenge Saving' Mentality Amid Economic Uncertainty**
A new trend is emerging in China, where young people are adopting a 'Revenge Saving' mentality, cutting back on expenses and saving money. This is in contrast to the previous generation, who often spent more than they earned and accumulated debt. According to Shaun Rein, CEO of the China Market Research Group, 'the Chinese youth has a Revenge-Saving mentality.' Experts attribute this behavior to the economic uncertainty in China, with young people feeling the impact of a slowing economy. Christopher Beddor, deputy director of China research at Gavekal Dragonomics, said, 'young people probably feel the same thing as everyone else: the economy is just not doing well.' The Chinese government's data shows that household deposits grew by 11.8% in the first quarter of 2024, but the International Monetary Fund predicts a further slowdown to 4.5% in the coming year. The youth unemployment rate in China is also high, at 14.2% in May 2024, and many young people are struggling to find jobs or increase their income. As a result, they are adopting a more frugal lifestyle, with some even eating in community kitchens for older people to save money. This trend is in stark contrast to the global Generation Z, who are more likely to take on debt to improve their quality of life. A study by Intuit found that 73% of Gen Z in the US would prioritize a higher quality of life over saving money.

The Chinese government has announced plans to raise the retirement age for the first time since 1978, allowing men to retire at 63 and women in physically demanding and skilled jobs to retire at 58, up from 55.
